title: Review specifically for Linux OS and Ryzen 3/5 3200G/3400G users
content: Just wanted to give a heads up to other Linux OS users.I built a system with a new ASUS Prime B450M-A motherboard, Ryzen 3 3200G, Crucial 3000 CL15 16GB DDR4 ram, a 120GB SSD and a Corsair 400W powering it all.As long as you stick to a Linux OS that has either specifically worked their OS to work with these newer chips (props to Ubuntu 18.04.3 LTS plus all 19* releases and Fedora 31 here), you will be ok.  Just know that (regrettably, AMD has forgotten who saved them years ago when the Intel assault was in full swing) you will not get support from AMD Linux-drivers-wise for these chips.  If you are aware of that, then you'll be good to go.  And know that these chips are not true AMD cpu 3000 releases; the true 3000 releases will come next summer).Using this chip, I watched an Ubuntu 18.04.3 LTS ISO boot straight up (on the ASUS Prime B450M-A mentioned above, I cannot speak about if this is so from other board manufacturers).  Same goes for Fedora 31.What wouldn't boot for me (without jumping thru hoops and rebuilding an ISO using a Linux kernel 5 or higher) were things like:  Linux Mint 19, OpenSUSE LEAP/Tumbleweed, Debian 10.1 Buster, MX-Linux 19 and a few others I tried.  They all fail to boot because most of them are still using kernels below 5).I put this new system in the living room, for the family & kids, and it has been enduring their abuse for the past few weeks without one hiccup (knock on wood, haha) or problem.  They use it for everything, from general web surfing, multi-purpose functions, to streaming Netflix, etc, etc.  I even used the included cooler and also convinced myself (as a test) to use the included paste it came with.  Honestly, so far,  I am still surprised at the normal temp range it has been easily running at no matter what they are doing.  Though if the gaming becomes heavy (its surprising what this chip will do FPS-wise, for 720P, it just rips thru everything like butter), I may swap the stock cooler out and install one of the bigger Thermaltake coolers I have (just to be safe).Hope this review helps anyone out there worried that this chip wouldn't run any Linux OS.  AMD needs to be slapped upside the head for last years Pinnacle Ridge debacle (which turned many, many Linux users off).  Thankfully, they've made a few strides with this 3200G/3400G releases, which is welcome.  Also note AMD is still telling all 300/400 series motherboard manufacturers to "disable" PCIe4 (AMD might deserve another slap upside the head for this).  If PCIe4 is important to you, wait for the true 3000 cpu(s) to be released next summer.Hope this review helps any Linux OS wonderers/users out there.

title: Excellent for budget gaming PCs
content: I currently use Ryzen 7 with RTX 2080 gpu on my main gaming PC, and I bought this Ryzen 3 cpu specifically for my son's gaming PC.  At first I was skeptical if this might bottleneck on modern gaming titles, but I was surprised it held up pretty well.I partnered this cpu with some spare parts lying around, gpu is Radeon Vega 56, RAM is corsair vengeance 16GB dual  @3000MHz.  I didn't use any bench marking tools as they are not really exact representations of real world usage.  Instead, I just started playing some modern games including Destiny 2, COD MW, and Fortnite.  I was impressed that CPU usage was just averaging on 50% to 60% with some very rare occasional spikes.  So, I'm pretty confident that this will be sufficient for my son's gaming needs.  Even on his daily school work, this cpu is more than enough.  Now, if you are a creator that uses software that utilizes multi thread processing a lot like Adobe creative suites, Blender, CAD software, etc, then this CPU may not suite your needs and you may want to get something on the higher end.  Although this CPU can still work fine with those software, but the time to process specific tasks may take a little longer.If you will ask why I purchased this cpu that has integrated graphics instead of Ryzen 5 2600 for  20 dollars more?  Well, sometimes discreet GPUs will fail and I don't have spare anymore.  So, in case the GPU fails, we can still use the integrated graphics to cover some daily tasks like school work.Overall, I'm very happy with my decision to buy this.  Saved me some money and yet can still perform perfectly fine with modern gaming titles.

title: Great Choice For Budget Builds
content: (Not a pc genius but I know the basics so if you're like me or know absolutely nothing about computers, here ya go) If you are a gamer on a budget, this is a GREAT option. My budget was $450 and I kept the full cost of my pc to around $445. If you have a slightly higher budget/like $50 more to spend, I suggest getting the Ryzen 5 3400G but if you don't play super demanding games or you REALLY don't have the money to spare, the Ryzen 3 3200G is amazing. I paired it with 16gb dual channel ddr4 ram and a 1tb hard drive and it runs great. I tried out Minecraft with Optifine and shaders because it was the first game to get done downloading and I gotta say : coming from an old i5-2320 + 16b ddr3 + 500gb hard drive, this new setup blew me away. I went from 45-60fps base game to 60-150fps+ base game. 20-40fps with shaders to 45-120fps (depending on the shaderpack). With that in mind, games like Fortnite, Sims, CSGO, Valorant, Elder Scrolls Online, Conan Exiles, and anything else around that requirement level should run well at medium settings (or higher for games like Sims and CSGO) depending on any other components you pair with this apu. One of my favorite parts of owning this apu (or any apu in general) is that if you don't have the money for a cpu + gpu combo, just grab one of these and hold off on a gpu until you can afford it. If you do add in a graphics card later on though, the performance should REALLY improve (depending on the card you choose of course). The stock cooler that comes in the box isn't great but it should get the job done until you're able to upgrade. If you just do some web browsing, watching movies/videos, the occasional small game, etc, I think this will be great for you. If you're into slightly more demanding games but okay with not having the BEST graphics settings imaginable and you're happy with medium settings and playable frame rates/low settings and better framerates, I think you'll enjoy this. And if you are into more AAA titles but can't afford the specs to play them, I would still say go for the 3400G but this is a solid 2nd place/placeholder until you can afford better upgrades. After adding a (decent) graphics card, if you feel the need to upgrade from this apu, you can buy an actual cpu to go with your new gpu which will make for an even better gaming setup.Overall I think this is a great choice for budget/entry level pc builds if nothing but a placeholder, I can see myself using this for years to come, just research the spec requirements for the games you are going to be playing. Don't buy this expecting performance from the latest and greatest pc components that are double-triple the price and I think you'll be satisfied.⭐⭐⭐⭐

content: It's an excellent APU to keep on hand, because it enables testing of the onboard video system of motherboards. It runs very cool and it tolerates questionable power really well from cheap power supplies and low spec VRMs. The onboard video turns out to be pretty good if you have fast dual channel ram and your mainboard memory bandwidth is good. Not having dual channel RAM really hurts the Vega 8 on this chip.For single thread applications, a boosted 3200G comes very close to a stock Ryzen 5 3600, but if you clock up the Ryzen 5 just a little bit, it will blow this 3200G out of the water. Don't buy this CPU to be your only PC, unless you really have to scrape the low end of cost, or you must fit a case that cannot accommodate a graphics card. I recommend spending just a little more and going with a Ryzen 5.

title: Works ok once you get all the software just right
content: In the early days of AMD I was a fan and built lots of AMD based computers.  Then the quality of their CPUs seemed to go south with bugs and compatibility problems so I went Intel all the way.  Then the Ryzen processors came out and I heard all sorts of good things, so when my mom's computer needed rebuilding I decided to try doing the build with a Ryzen.  The regret started almost immediately.  Windows 10 crashed on install, then with a BIOS update it installed but wouldn't update.  Figuring out all the compatibility issues with Windows 10 resulted in long hours and bloodshot eyes but I finally figured out the magical combination of drivers and bios to get it to function correctly.  But what a huge pain and waste of time!  While I did get this to work in the end, I can't in good conscience recommend it to anyone, there is no excuse for something so basic to be that complicated in the 21st century.  Suffice to say I am going back to Intel.
